channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: West Struggles to Halt Flow of Citizens to War Zones
item.description: The attacks in France have given new urgency to American and European efforts to prevent their citizens from going to Muslim countries to fight, and possibly becoming threats back home.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Letter From Europe: Standing Up for the Pen vs. the Sword in France
item.description: Restraints are often put on offensive words, sometimes by law, sometimes by unwritten code. But in the face of threats of violence and death, any expression is nonnegotiable.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Cuba Frees 53 Prisoners, U.S. Says
item.description: Those freed have been identified by human rights organizations as having been jailed for promoting political reforms or trying to exercise free speech.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Joan Peters, Journalist Who Wrote on Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Dies at 78
item.description: In a 1984 book, both widely hailed and criticized, she cited historical documents showing that Arab settlers had flocked to Palestine beginning in the late 1800s; they had not, she wrote, inhabited the land “from time immemorial.”
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK
item.media:description: Joan Peters in an image published by Harper & Row in 1984.

item.title: Big Anti-Immigration Rally in Germany Prompts Counterdemonstrations
item.description: Rallies called by anti-immigration forces have led their political opponents in cities like Dresden and Leipzig to organize counterdemonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Tens of thousands rallied Monday in Dresden in support of Pegida, a group that opposes is immigration. The poster reads, “Mrs. Merkel here are the people!”

item.title: Fox News Beats a Retreat After Gaffes About Islam
item.description: The Fox News Channel incited an outpouring of ridicule with suggestions that all followers of Islam be held responsible for the Paris attacks.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Divers Working to Retrieve AsiaAir Jet’s Cockpit Voice Recorder
item.description: Search and salvage workers were preparing on Tuesday to move debris of the AirAsia plane wreckage to allow divers to retrieve the cockpit voice recorder, the search coordinator said
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Obama Assures Netanyahu That U.S. Opposes Palestinians’ Bid to Join Court
item.description: President Obama told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday that the United States opposed the Palestinian Authority’s bid to join the International Criminal Court, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Fear on Rise, Jews in France Weigh an Exit
item.description: Unsure of their future in France, French Jews are increasingly willing to consider conflict-torn Israel as a safer refuge.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A soldier Monday outside a school in the Marais, a traditionally Jewish neighborhood of Paris. The display of muscle recalled the United States response after the Sept. 11 attacks.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jimmy Lai on the Democracy Movement in Hong Kong
item.description: Jimmy Lai, who has come under attack for his anti-Communist views, speaks about his role in the Occupy Central protests, why he is distancing himself from his media company and the challenges that lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH and ALAN WONG
item.media:credit: Brent Lewin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai, the founder and owner of Next Media. He was a central figure in the Occupy Central movement in Hong Kong.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For China, a New Leader in Sri Lanka May Herald a Change in Ties
item.description: Beijing is likely to be watching with some unease to see if the surprise victor in Sri Lanka’s election follows through on a promise to scrap a major Chinese investment project.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Maithripala Sirisena, who won Sri Lanka's presidential election Thusday, has taken rhetorical aim at foreign-backed development projects.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Firebombs Thrown at Jimmy Lai’s Home and Company in Hong Kong
item.description: The headquarters of the Next Media Group and the home of its owner, Jimmy Lai, were targeted but suffered no significant property damage.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A security guard outside the house of the Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai after it was firebombed early Monday.

item.title: Francesco Rosi, Giant of Italian Cinema, Dies at 92
item.description: Mr. Rosi’s commitment to social issues made him a direct heir to the traditions of Italian neorealist cinema of the postwar years.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ANDERSON
item.media:description: Francesco Rosi in Paris on the set of his movie “Carmen” in 1984, played an instrumental part in the highly politicized post-neorealist Italian cinema of the 1960s and ’70s.

item.title: White House Acknowledges Error in Not Sending a Top Official to March in Paris
item.description: Criticism of the minor part played by Americans in a rally against terrorism has stung President Obama’s staff.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Strains Show as Afghan Leaders Announce Long-Awaited Cabinet Nominees
item.description: Choosing a cabinet proved difficult for President Ashraf Ghani and his rival Abdullah Abdullah, who jointly lead the government.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: France Deploys Troops to Guard ‘Sensitive Sites’
item.description: The authorities said that they would bolster security to protect potential targets of terrorism, putting in place one of the country’s biggest peacetime security operations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: French troop members at the Eiffel Tower on Monday were part of an increased security presence.

item.title: Libyan Militants Aligned With Islamic State Claim Kidnapping of 21 Egyptian Christians
item.description: The group claiming to have seized the hostages identified itself as the Tripolitania Province of the Islamic State, named for the region around the capital, Tripoli, in western Libya.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: ISIS Is Cited in Hacking of Central Command’s Twitter and YouTube Accounts
item.description: Messages posted on the U.S. military accounts, the hackers claimed, listed the names and phone numbers of military personnel, but the documents appeared to be public records.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: The hacked Twitter page of U.S. Central Command.

item.title: In China, Projects to Make Great Wall Feel Small
item.description: Despite economic choppiness, the country that built the Great Wall is attaining new superlatives in bridges, tunnels, rail links and other projects of immense size — and expense.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Interpol Calls for Arrest of Yanukovych and Other Former Ukrainian Officials
item.description: The directive, called a red notice, does not compel any nation to arrest the officials, but declares them to be wanted in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
